Unfortunately, she is out of this herb, and the only way to get more of it is to search the Wicked Forest. He/she| considers telling the family that they would have to be the ones to do this, but his/her| conscience tells him/her| that it is his/her| duty, besides which they might not recognize it and pick the wrong plant. Also the gold helps.

After a moment, he/she| realizes that his/her| shadow didn't stop walking when he/she| did. He/she| backs away slowly as his/her| shadow gets further and further away from him/her|. He/she| decides to start searching in a different direction.

event.p: A mushroom circle lies just along |'s path, but he/she| is so busy looking for a |Plant plant that he/she| walks straight towards it.

success.p: Fortunately, | sees it just before stepping inside. After a moment of letting his/her| heart calm down, he/she| says a prayer of thanks to you and resumes searching in a different direction.

danger.p: Unfortunately, by the time | notices it she was already inside. Desperately, he/she| turns around and starts to run out of it.

averted.p: Miraculously, he/she| makes it out. He/she| continues the search.

failure.p: Unfortunately, he/she| sees a leprechaun between him/her| and the mushroom border. “Welcome, mortal!” it says to him/her| cheerfully. “I am sure you will have a wonderful time in our land.”

His/her| time in the fairy world feels like a dream; when it is all over, he/she| can hardly remember what it had been like. He/she| finds himself/herself| standing in the forest in the bright light of day, with mushrooms nowhere to be seen. He/she| runs back to the village, but it is no longer there--at least, as she remembered it. The houses are not in the same place and were larger, the dirt roads are now covered with some black material and have strange shiny creatures on them, and branchless trees are everywhere with black rope strung between them for unknown reasons. He/she| has no idea how much time he/she| had spent away from the world, but she knew that |Child, as well as everyone else he/she| had known and loved, was certainly dead.

event.shame: | was teleported by You to a distant realm through the enigmatic magic of the fairies, and there was no way to make it back in time to save |Child.

branch.title: Some Help Arrives?
branch.question: Who is it?
branch.p: Finally, just when all hope is lost, a creature arrives to help |.

event.p: | hears a meow. He/she| looks to the source, and sees a forest cat. It is hard to see the color of the cat, which is a problem because it is the best way of being able to tell whether the cat is evil or not.

The cat beckons to him/her| and starts walking. Should he/she| follow the cat? As trepidatious as he/she| is feeling about the situation, he/she| does really need to get the herb as soon as he/she| can, and this is the best lead he/she| has had all night. He/she| decides to roll the dice and follow the cat.

success.p: He/she| follows the cat for some time, and eventually it stops. It picks something up and brings it to him/her|. Excitedly, she bends down to look at it.

He/she| growls and tosses the mouse to the side. He/she| starts to walk away when he/she| realizes that the cat is sitting right next to a |Plant plant. A beam of moonlight reveals that the cat has green fur.
Well, cats are cats, even the good ones.
He/she| walks over and picks the plant, and then scratches the cat. “Good kitty!” he/she| says. It purrs.

danger.p: | chases after the cat, barely able to keep up. It is because of this that he/she| does not notice that she is stepping into a pit.

averted.p: | follows into the pit but somehow avoids getting any broken bones. He/she| looks up in time to see the cat, its blue fur finally shown clearly in a beam of moonlight, flash him/her| a cheshire grin and vanish.
| grumbles at the existence of mischievous malevolent cats, but at least he/she| notices a |Plant herb at the bottom so she can start heading home.

failure.title: Can't Get Up
failure.p: Too late he/she| realizes that he/she| is stepping into a pit. Unable to catch himself/herself| in time, he/she| falls into the put, breaking a leg. The cat looks down into the pit, its fur clearly revealed to be blue in the moonlight, and flashes him/her| a cheshire grin, after which it vanishes. | growls in anger and then faints in pain. |Child will not be getting the medicine that he/she|Child desperately needs tonight...

event.shame: You caused | to act against their better judgement in following a forest cat at night without knowing its color.
You taught | the hard way that chasing after random forest cats in the middle of the night is a bad plan.

event.title: Running After a Fairy

event.p: | starts to hear a sound and he/she| can't tell whether it is a buzzing or the most beautiful music he/she| has ever heard. As it gets louder he/she| notices the area around him/her| starting to get brighter. He/she| looks around and sees a fairy, glowing brightly in the dark. The fairy beckons to him/her|, and then flies away. | hesitates briefly, and then runs after the fairy.

success.title: A Successful Chase
success.p: | chases the fairy for about an hour, starting to doubt whether this is such a good idea, when the fairy stops. He/she| catches up to it and sees an |Plant plant under it. Carefully, he/she| reaches down and picks it. When he/she| looks up, the fairy is gone.
He/she| falls to his/her| knees and thanks You for guiding him/her| to the plant. He/she| then gets up and starts heading back to his/her| home.

danger.title: Can't Stop Chasing

danger.p: The chase after the fairy becomes faster and faster, but unfortunately | does not seem to be able to break free of its grip.

averted.title: Slammed Into a Tree
averted.p: Suddenly the run ends with | slamming into a tree. She falls to the ground. After a few moments, she gets up, nursing splitting headache. Miracuously, she finds a |Plant at the bottom of the tree. She picks it and returns home.

failure.title: Passage of Time
failure.p: | runs faster and faster to catch up with the fairy. Everything starts to blur until there is only him/her| and the fairy. Eventually it all fades to black.
| wakes up to the sounds of birds singing. After a moment of disorientation, he/she| realizes that he/she| is still in the forest, and it is now morning. She weeps, for surely by now |Child is dead.

event.shame: You made | fail to realize that chasing after a random fairy was a bad idea.
You made | learn the hard way that not all fairies are good fairies.

narrative.title: Full Moon
narrative.p: | looks up at the Moon. For reasons that nobody understands, the Moon is always full in the Wicked Forest. The good news is that this makes it easier to search for |Plant, but the bad news is that he/she| has to worry about werewolves...

narrative.title: Talking Tree
narrative.p: “Hello, human. It isn't often that I get to see one of your kind here.”
| jumps and looks around for the source of the voice. He/she| hears it laugh. “You are just as stupid as the rest of your kind. Look, I am over here.”
| finally realizes that the voice was coming from the tree right next to him/her|.

“Why are you here?” it asks. | replies, “I am looking for a |Plant plant. I down't suppose you have seen one?” It laughs. “Do I look like I have legs?” | replies, “Umm, no, I guess not; I guess I'll just be going on my way then...”
| resumes searching, the laugher of the tree receding as he/she| leaves it behind.

success.p: Not long after arriving, he/she| makes it back to his/her| hut and immediately starts brewing medicine for |Child. He/she| takes it to the family’s hut and gives it to them to administer to |Child. It is true that he/she| had just risked life and limb to save a single person, but he/she| considers it to be well worth it. Also they pay her a bonus.

He/she| returns to his/her| own hut and does not even have enough energy to make it to the bed; she falls asleep on the floor, though with a smile on his/her| face. The next day, he/she| builds an altar to You out of gratitude.

danger.choice: Yes, come to think of it...

danger.p: He/she starts to breathe a sigh of relief when he/she| realizes that something is off that he/she| cannot quite place. As he/she| got closer, he/she| realizes that the doors to the huts are all facing him/her|, and that they seem to always be facing him/her| no matter how close he/she| gets to the village. averted.p: When in or close to the Wicked Forest, it is best to trust one’s instincts. Thus, even though it was the last thing that | wanted to do, he/she| turns around and walks back into the forest.

After wandering for another hour, he/she| again sees huts, but this time he/she| does not get the same feeling of wrongness so he/she| cautiously approaches them. Again, nothing seems amiss so he/she| enters the village and heads towards his/her| hut. He/she| immediately starts brewing medicine for |Child and then takes it to the family’s hut and gives it to them to administer to |Child. It is true that he/she| had just risked life and limb to save a single person, but he/she| considers it to be well worth it. Also they pay him/her| a bonus.

He/she| returns to his/her| own hut and does not even have enough energy to make it to the bed; he/she| falls asleep on the floor, though with a smile on his/her| face. The next day, he/she| builds an altar to you out of gratitude.

failure.p: He/she| dismisses the notion; it had been a long night and the most likely explanation was that his/her| mind was going after his/her| long search in the Wicked Forest. Besides which, most importantly, he/she| needs to prepare the medication for |Child as quickly as possible. He/she| heads quickly to his/her| hut and opens the door. To His/her| shock, he/she| sees himself/herself| inside--but it wasn’t quite him/her|. After a moment, he/she| realizes what was wrong: the thing inside is flat, as if it were made of paper. Both | and the thing say simultaneously, “What are you?”

| yelps in pain. He/she| looks down at his/her| arms and sees that they are getting flatter. The thing smiles, “I guess you are one of us now.” | notices that he/she| can see straight through the thing's own mouth whenever it opens.
Well, maybe in this strange world he/she| could at least do some good. He/she| asks, “How is |Child?”
| starts to weep in pain and anguish but as his/her| head flattens the tears are unable to push themselves out of his/her| tear ducts.
“Don’t worry,” says the thing. “You will be safe here, with us.
